sense.name: a long, thin implement, usually made of wood
sense.examples: That outdoor store sells some very good hi-tech hiking sticks. The girl used a large stick to herd the chickens into their coop. The government has used tax policies as both a carrot and a stick. (metaphoric extension) The conductor raised his stick in preparation to begin the performance.

sense.name: long thin sports equipment used for hitting balls
sense.examples: The hockey players clubbed each other with their sticks. The polo sticks hung above the saddles in the tack room of the stable.

sense.name: a small tree branch, twigs
sense.commentary: STICK[+structure][+tree][+branch][+small] Note: refers to natural objects, not artifacts (see Sense 1)
sense.examples: We gathered sticks near the campsite to make a fire. The young saplings by the river are just green sticks that can snap back if bent. The x-ray showed that the injury to the bone was just a green stick break. (figurative extension)

sense.name: a control lever, as for an aircraft or car
sense.examples: Bob drives a stick shift. The pilot pulled back on the stick and the plane lifted from the runway. The co-pilot took the stick from the pilot.

sense.name: anything with the form of a thin strip
sense.examples: Mary set out a plate of carrot and celery sticks. He offered me a stick of chewing gum. The demolition expert placed sticks of dynamite in key structural places of the building. The apple cider should simmer for half an hour with a couple of cinnamon sticks. We're having fish sticks for dinner.

sense.name: a volume measure, e.g. butter
sense.examples: This pie crust contains a stick of butter. There are four sticks of butter in a pound. They sell hydrogenated vegetable oil in sticks at the grocery store.

sense.name: the boondocks, backwater locale
sense.commentary: STICK[+location][+locale][+rustic][+boondocks] Note: always occurs in the plural
sense.examples: He grew up in the sticks and never visited a city until he was in the Army. We were surprised to find a gourmet coffee shop so far out in the sticks.

sense.name: a marijuana cigarette
sense.examples: He pulled out a couple of sticks at the concert to pass among his friends. A marijuana stick fell out of her purse right in front of the border guard.

sense.name: a dull, stiff, inert person
sense.examples: Betty can be such an old stick sometimes! Her husband seems like such a stick at parties.

sense.name: strong adhesive quality
sense.examples: This masking tape has a lot of stick to it. There isn't much stick left to these old stamps.

sense.name: a small number of something
sense.examples: A stick of paratroopers dropped from a plane into enemy territory. The dictator was surrounded by a stick of heavily armed guards. The bomber released a stick of bombs over the target area.

sense.name: a piece of furniture
sense.examples: The robbers took every last stick of furniture in the house. There wasn't a stick of furniture to sit on in the whole lobby. I haven't even moved one stick of lawn furniture out of the basement yet.

sense.name: severe criticism
sense.examples: He's taken a lot of stick from the press lately.

sense.name: human legs, informal usage
sense.examples: The sailor joked that his sticks were getting old. (his legs - figurative extension of sense 1)
